title: Proposed Texas GOP platform calls for the Bible in schools, electoral changes that would lock Democrats out of statewide office
text: Proposed Texas GOP platform calls for the Bible in schools, electoral changes that would lock Democrats out of statewide office [Sign up for The Brief](https://www.texastribune.org/newsletters/the-brief/?utm_medium=website&utm_source=trib-ads-owned&utm_campaign=trib-marketing&utm_term=inline-CTA-brief), The Texas Tribune‚Äôs daily newsletter that keeps readers up to speed on the most essential Texas news. Republican Party of Texas delegates voted Saturday on a platform that called for new laws to require the Bible to be taught in public schools and a constitutional amendment that would require statewide elected leaders to win the popular vote in a majority of Texas counties. Other proposed planks of the 50-page platform included proclamations that ‚Äúabortion is not healthcare it is homicide‚Äù; that gender-transition treatment for children is ‚Äúchild abuse‚Äù; calls to reverse recent name changes to military bases and ‚Äúpublicly honor the southern heroes‚Äù; support for declaring gold and silver as legal tender; and demands that the U.S. government disclose ‚Äúall pertinent information and knowledge‚Äù of UFOs. The party hopes to finalize its platform on Wednesday, after Saturday‚Äôs votes on each proposal are tabulated. Passed by delegates at the party‚Äôs biennial convention, the platform has traditionally been seen not as a definitive list of Republican stances, but a compromise document that represents the interests of the party‚Äôs various business, activist and social conservative factions. But in recent years ‚Äî and amid a party civil war that‚Äôs pushed it further right ‚Äî the platform has been increasingly [used as a basis](https://www.texastribune.org/2024/05/23/texas-gop-matt-rinaldi-republicans/) for censuring Republican officeholders who the party‚Äôs far right has attacked as insufficiently conservative, including Texas House Speaker Dade Phelan, R-Beaumont, and U.S. Rep. Tony Gonzalez, R-San Antonio. As the party has drifted further right, its platform has done the same. In 2022, it called for a referendum on [Texas secession](https://www.texastribune.org/2023/11/15/texas-secession-texit/); resistance to the ‚ÄúGreat Reset,‚Äù a conspiracy theory that claims global elites are using environmental and social policies to enslave the world‚Äôs population; proclamations that homosexuality is an ‚Äúabnormal lifestyle choice‚Äù; and a declaration that President Joe Biden was [not legitimately elected](https://www.texastribune.org/2022/06/18/texas-state-republican-convention/). Many of those planks were also included in this year‚Äôs platform, which was debated late into Friday night and presented for a vote Saturday afternoon. One proposal asserts that illegal immigration is the ‚Äúgreatest threat to American security and sovereignty‚Äù and calls for the state and federal governments to devote all available resources to deporting undocumented immigrants. Perhaps the most consequential plank calls for a constitutional amendment to require that candidates for statewide office carry a majority of Texas‚Äô 254 counties to win an election, a model similar to the U.S. electoral college. Under current voting patterns, in which Republicans routinely win in the state‚Äôs rural counties, such a requirement would effectively end Democrats‚Äô chances of winning statewide office. In 2022, Gov. Greg Abbott carried 235 counties, while Democrat Beto O‚ÄôRourke carried most of the urban, more populous counties and South Texas counties. Statewide, Abbott won 55% of the popular vote while O‚ÄôRourke carried 44%. However, some attorneys question whether such a proposal would be constitutional and conform with the Voting Rights Act because it would most likely limit the voting power of racial minorities, who are concentrated in a relatively small number of counties. (The party‚Äôs platform also reiterates its previous calls for the repeal of the Voting Rights Act). The platform also takes a step further some of the party‚Äôs previous calls for more [Christianity in public life](https://www.texastribune.org/2023/05/04/texas-legislature-church-state-separation/). The 2022 platform proclaimed that the United States was ‚Äúfounded on Judeo-Christian principles,‚Äù for instance, and demanded the repeal of federal prohibitions on political activity by churches. The 2024 platform goes significantly further: It urges lawmakers and the State Board of Education to ‚Äúrequire instruction on the Bible, servant leadership and Christian self-governance,‚Äù and supports the use of religious chaplains in schools ‚Äî which was [made legal](https://www.texastribune.org/2023/05/19/legislature-chaplain-bill-rocky-malloy/) under a law passed by the state Legislature last year. Though more subtle, another proposed plank could also aid Republicans‚Äô ongoing attempts to further infuse Christianity into public education. This year‚Äôs platform also calls for Thomas Jefferson‚Äôs ‚ÄúLetter to the Danbury Baptists‚Äù to be included in the list of ‚Äúoriginal founding documents‚Äù to be taught in history classes, along with the U.S. Constitution or The Federalist Papers. Jefferson‚Äôs Danbury letter is often cited by activists such as [David Barton](https://www.texastribune.org/2023/11/03/david-barton-mike-johnson-texas-church-state-christianity/), a Texas pastor and self-described ‚Äúamateur historian‚Äù who has spent decades arguing that church-state separation is a ‚Äúmyth‚Äù that has been [used to shroud](https://www.texastribune.org/2022/07/29/texas-church-state-separation-opposition/) America‚Äôs true Christian roots ‚Äî a claim that has been [thoroughly debunked](https://religionnews.com/2023/12/01/warren-throckmorton-takes-on-david-barton-and-christian-nationalist-revision-history-in-revised-jefferson-book/) by actual historians and experts, many of them also [conservative Christians](https://www.theatlantic.com/national/archive/2012/08/genuine-christian-scholars-smack-down-an-unruly-colleague/260994/). The new platform comes as Republicans increasingly embrace once-fringe theories such as Christian nationalism, which argues that the United States‚Äô founding was God-ordained, and therefore its institutions and laws should reflect conservative, Christian views. Barton‚Äôs ideas have been a [key driver](https://www.texastribune.org/2023/11/03/david-barton-mike-johnson-texas-church-state-christianity/) of that movement, and were [repeatedly cited](https://www.texastribune.org/2023/05/04/texas-legislature-church-state-separation/) by lawmakers last year during debates over the chaplains bill and in legislation that would have required the Ten Commandments to be posted in public school classrooms. Barton‚Äôs group, WallBuilders, was also an exhibitor at this year‚Äôs Texas GOP convention, and the party has [increasingly aligned](https://www.texastribune.org/2024/05/23/texas-gop-matt-rinaldi-republicans/) with two far-right, fundamentalist Christian billionaires, Tim Dunn and Farris Wilks. The draft platform also leans into the Texas GOP‚Äôs open hostility toward Texas House leadership and Phelan, with positions that would weaken the power of the House speaker and distribute power to the GOP caucus in the House as a whole. One plank advocates for limiting the speaker to two consecutive terms. Another calls for a discharge petition process, which would allow members to send bills to the House floor for a vote even if they haven‚Äôt passed the House committee process. On Friday night, the convention elected former Collin County GOP Chair Abraham George as the [next party chair](https://www.texastribune.org/2024/05/24/texas-republican-party-chair-abraham-george/), a vote that is expected to continue the party‚Äôs trajectory. During his candidate speech on Thursday, George called for the party to fight Democrats, radicals and ‚ÄúRINO‚Äù Republicans who go against ‚Äúeverything we stand for.‚Äù During a speech on the convention stage on Saturday, former gubernatorial candidate and state Sen. Don Huffines carried a printed version of the platform with him. He noted that Republicans have controlled the Legislature and the governor‚Äôs mansion for two decades, but the party still struggles to secure its priorities. ‚ÄúWe could get any piece of legislation done anytime we want, but, every session, we struggle to get our platform into law,‚Äù Huffines said. We‚Äôve got big things in store for you at [The Texas Tribune Festival](https://trib.it/X3GApE), happening Sept. 5‚Äì7 in downtown Austin. Join us for three days of big, bold conversations about politics, public policy and the day‚Äôs news. This article originally appeared in [The Texas Tribune](http://www.texastribune.org/) at [https://www.texastribune.org/2024/05/25/texas-republican-party-convention-platform/](https://www.texastribune.org/2024/05/25/texas-republican-party-convention-platform/). author: Becca Lower
title: 'These People Are a Fraud': Trump Delivers Remarks on Harris Border Crisis, 'Phony' Jobs Numbers, More ‚Äì RedState
text: Former President Trump made a statement to the media at Trump Tower in Manhattan Thursday afternoon, covering a wide swath of topics, including the incompetence of his opponent, Democrat presidential nominee, Vice President Kamala Harris, who is scheduled to visit the U.S.-Mexico border while on the campaign trail on Friday. üö®President Trump to Deliver Press Remarks at Trump Tower at 4:30PM ET ‚Äî Karoline Leavitt (@kleavittnh)[pic.twitter.com/Ab2Oa8ncOJ][September 26, 2024] He began his remarks on the Harris border crisis, which he called "the worst border crisis in the history of the world," questioning why she would go to the border (e.g. such a gift to her political opponent's campaign): PRESIDENT TRUMP: For nearly 4 years, we have been living through the worst border crisis in the history of the world‚Äîwhich has brought untold suffering, misery, and death upon our land. ‚Äî Trump War Room (@TrumpWarRoom) The architect of this destruction is KAMALA HARRIS.[pic.twitter.com/ZkcrehkTN5][September 26, 2024] Calling VP Harris "a radical Left person," Trump ridiculed her previous "visit" to the border as "very mild and no danger." She was nowhere near the actual border areas. Trump half-jokingly said he should have called his remarks on Thursday his "Why Didn't She Do It?" speech. As in, why hasn't she done any of the things she's trying to promise people she will do, when she has been in office for almost four years in the Biden administration? Trump speculated on possible reasons they have left the border unprotected. The first reason, he said, is Incompetence; the second reason, is "They want it for the votes." He said that he didn't need to tell people the third reason, and that people could guess. He also spoke about the second presidential debate, which Trump took part in against Harris on ABC News, and being improperly corrected by co-moderator David Muir. In what might be breaking news, Trump asserted that his campaign had a deal in advance with the producers of the debate that no fact-checking would happen. He said, "They violated the deal. Why? They're bad people and they're fake news." Read related: [ABC Whistleblower Says Harris Camp Allegedly 'Restricted the Scope' of Trump Debate Questions](https://redstate.com/beccalower/2024/09/15/breaking-abc-whistleblower-says-harris-campaign-allegedly-restricted-the-scope-of-debate-questions-n2179354) Then Trump shared some crime numbers in NYC on illegal aliens, and in Albany, NY, about a woman being brutally raped, then spoke about other horrors allegedly committed across the country--many thousands of miles from the Southern border: PRESIDENT TRUMP: "Here in New York City, an estimated 75 percent of arrests in Midtown Manhattan and over 60 percent of arrests in Queens are now illegal aliens... It's going to STOP starting on January 20th." ‚Äî Trump War Room (@TrumpWarRoom)[pic.twitter.com/nVhTwsvSgJ][September 26, 2024] PRESIDENT TRUMP: "In Albany last May, an illegal alien who was caught and released by Kamala Harris, stalked and raped a 15-year-old girl, driving up behind her, abducting her by force with a metal pipe, and raping her again and again." ‚Äî Trump War Room (@TrumpWarRoom)[pic.twitter.com/xEWxFRHA31][September 26, 2024] While admitting that ":there's nothing nice" about the stories he's talking about, whether on the border, the economy, or any other issue made worse by Joe Biden and Kamala Harris. Trump pressed the issue once again, asking why Harris has not done what she says she wants to do if elected as president, in a look toward November's elections. Those were his exact words: "Why hasn't she done it?" PRESIDENT TRUMP: Despite all of this, Kamala Harris intends to stand before the American People tomorrow and LIE, pretending she wants a secure border. But if that were true, WHY HASN‚ÄôT SHE DONE IT? ‚Äî Trump War Room (@TrumpWarRoom)[pic.twitter.com/JBD0iFFE6C][September 26, 2024] Just as he did during the debate, Trump swiftly destroyed her excuses on the border problem festering on her watch: PRESIDENT TRUMP: You will hear Kamala claim that the reason the border is not secure is that Congress has refused to pass her atrocious Border bill. But it was NOT a Border Bill‚Äîit was an AMNESTY Bill. ‚Äî Trump War Room (@TrumpWarRoom)[pic.twitter.com/PzEjjHnOql][September 26, 2024] Staying on the general election topic, he said he reckons that his and Vance's campaign is "up 21 points." Read related: [Gallup Drops Stunner of a Poll for Trump That Could be the Game Changer](https://redstate.com/nick-arama/2024/09/26/gallup-poll-is-not-good-for-kamala-n2179802) One of the money quotes from Trump also nailed the importance of conservatives getting out the vote, in fact: "Without borders and without fair elections, we have no country," he said. Then, returning to immigration, he spoke about Americans being terrorized and hurt by illegal alien gangs in places like Aurora, Colorado, and Springfield, Ohio: PRESIDENT TRUMP: Every state is now a border state‚Äîand Kamala Harris is the reason why. ‚Äî Trump War Room (@TrumpWarRoom) In Aurora, Colorado, Springfield, Ohio, and other towns just like them, Americans have watched their communities destroyed by a sudden and suffocating inundation of illegal aliens. This‚Ä¶[pic.twitter.com/PZ8XlXzahI][September 26, 2024] He ended by listing what he and Vance will do (some actions on Day 1) to end the border crisis: President Trump's plan to secure our border: ‚Äî Trump War Room (@TrumpWarRoom) - Stop all migrant flights - Shut down all entries through the migrant phone app - End catch-and-release - Restore Remain in Mexico - Bring back Title 42 - Send in federal law enforcement to liberate Aurora, Colorado - Send Congress a‚Ä¶[pic.twitter.com/mLOivhf4GL][September 26, 2024] As this is a developing story, keep an eye out for updates in these pages as they emerge.
